sn21.10:1: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the Squirrel Sanctuary. Now on that occasion a certain bhikkhu named Elder[n.397]Aññataro bhikkhu theranāmako.Spkdoes not explain this peculiar name or further identify the monk.was a lone dweller and spoke in praise of dwelling alone. He entered the village for alms alone, he returned alone, he sat alone in private, he undertook walking meditation alone.
sn21.10:2: Then the Blessed One addressed a certain bhikkhu thus: "Come, bhikkhu, tell the bhikkhu Elder in my name that the Teacher calls him."
sn21.10:3: "That is a way of dwelling alone, Elder, I do not deny this. But as to how dwelling alone is fulfilled in detail, listen to that and attend closely, I will speak."
sn21.10:4: This is what the Blessed One said. Having said this, the Fortunate One, the Teacher, further said this:
sn21.10:5: "The wise one, all-conqueror, all-knower,Among all things unsullied, with all cast off,Liberated in the destruction of craving:I call that person ‘one who dwells alone.’"[n.399] The first three pādas are atSn 211and, with a variation, atDhp 33.Spk: All-conqueror(sabābhibhuṁ): one who abides having overcome all aggregates, sense bases, and elements, and the three kinds of existence. Unsullied (anupalittaṁ, or "unstuck") among those very things by the paste(lepa)of craving and views. Liberated in the destruction of craving(taṇhakkhaye vimuttaṁ): liberated in Nibbāna, called the destruction of craving by way of the liberation that takes this as its object.
